findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to perform transactions when the trading is not open, allowing them to take advantage of it by performing transactions when the trading is closed.

findings.title: PVC - Price Volatility Concern
findings.description: The contract accumulates tokens from taxes to swap them for ETH, but if `swapTokensAtAmount` is set to a big number, it may trigger a huge token swap, leading to significant price volatility due to the token's highly volatile price.

findings.title: RV - Redundant Variable
findings.description: The variable `walletToWalletTransferWithoutFee` is immutable and set to true. It is used in an if statement. Therefore, this variable is redundant and serves no functional purpose in the contract.

findings.title: PTRP - Potential Transfer Revert Propagation
findings.description: The contract sends funds to a `wallet01` as part of the transfer flow. This address can either be a wallet address or a contract. If the address belongs to a contract then it may revert from incoming payment. As a result, the error will propagate to the token’s contract and revert the transfer.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract is using variables that initialize them only in the constructor and are not mutated by other functions, but these variables are not defined as `immutable`.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure they cannot be changed after being set, which decreases gas consumption of the corresponding transaction.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: Non-conformance to Solidity naming conventions can lead to decreased readability and maintainability of the code.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract. They are often used to notify external parties or clients about events that have occurred within the contract, such as the transfer of tokens or the completion of a task.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can occur due to conditional statements that are always false, functions that are never called, or unreachable code, making a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and increasing its size and deployment cost.

findings.title: L16 - Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables configured by user-supplied input without proper checks for zero values, leading to potential problems during execution.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version can be used to compile the contract, which may lead to vulnerabilities and undiscovered bugs.

findings.title: L20 - Succeeded Transfer Check
findings.description: The transfer methods should be checked if the result is successful according to the ERC20 specification, otherwise, the contract may wrongly assume that the transfer has been established.
